pr_title: Fix a bug when check with entry prefix

timeline.message: Fix a bug when check with entry prefix, we ignored the pegasus entry name

timeline.bodyText:
I don't see why "parseSources" should load from both locations.
Based on my understanding: When SchemaDirectoryName == EXTENSION, the ExtensionSchemaResolver will be configured to resolve from both locations.
And parseSource should only parse the extension schemas, right?
timeline.author: karthikbalasub

replies.bodyText:
The reason for doing this change is for users who don't want to create two parsers to call parse sources twice.
The other reason is that when I add the condition in this FileFormatDataSchemaParser, I had the pegasus base entry in mind.
I also feel that extension schema only also make sense.
For the other question that resolve from both location, it is true, and it is in my existing unit test cases.
replies.author: BrianPin

replies.bodyText: After offline discussion, I removed the support of parsing pegasus PDL by ExtensionSchemaResolver
replies.author: BrianPin

timeline.bodyText:
I'd like to make a comment on the original condition logic itself. It took me a while to understand what this if-statement is checking for because it's unnecessarily convoluted. The original logic basically said:
if entryName.startsWith(schemasDirectoryName) or isExtensionEntry()
...where isExtensionEntry() checks that the schemas directory name is extensions and that the entry name starts with extensions/
Couldn't this just be reduced to
if entryName.startsWith(schemasDirectoryName + '/')? Since if the schema directory name is extensions, then it would be checking that it starts with extensions/ anyway
Ignoring the fact that the name isExtensionEntry() is misleading and inaccurate (since it also checks the resolver's schemas directory name value, not just the entry), it doesn't even seem like this method is needed.
Since you're changing this logic, though, my suggestion is that you simplify this if-statement to make it more comprehensible.

timeline.bodyText:
I'm not sure what the original logic (before the SchemaDirectoryName change) looked like, but would it make sense to add a + "/" to the check? Otherwise cases like pegasusFoo/Foo.pdl would not be filtered out. However, we need to make sure we don't break existing behavior.


I'm curious about this bug. Why do we want to allow case-insensitive matches? I'll follow up offline.
timeline.author: evanw555

replies.bodyText:
For #1 , yeah more or less your idea is great, but the original logic is like this
For #2, it is because we add to jar with lower cases, but the directory name defined Resolver is in upper case. That is why we need case insensitive. Follow up with me offline anytime
replies.author: BrianPin

replies.bodyText:
If this is the case, ignoring the case is generally ok.
but why did we add to jar using lower case ?
replies.author: junchuanwang

replies.bodyText: It is one of the original choice I guess
replies.author: BrianPin

replies.bodyText:
When a enum is being used, the method name() will return its original form which in our case is all upper cases. On the other hand, the method getName() will return the actual coded content literal, which in our is all lower cases.
In the beginning of my very first PR of this parser, I was using name() so it is not matching the configured entry prefix in jar, but I have the isExtensionEntry to help to rescue.
